chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text:
$a)$ The discounted payback period refers to the time this takes for a project that recovers its initial expenses from the present value of future inflows, after calculating the net present value of all the cash flows, its cash flows were added till the total equals the investment cost, a discounted payback period calculates the number of cash flows needed to cover an investment's cost, taking into account its discounting factor.

This discounted payback period rule indicates that whenever the payback term will be shorter than its investment's life, that investment must be chosen.

$b)$ They are three problems of discounted payback period method below:

$i)$  When an investment has a greater discounted payback period, the discounted payback period technique can discard it.

$ii)$ when the cash inflows after the cut-off period are ignored by the payback period, this will be the phase of surplus inflow.

$iii)$ Because discounted values are required in the computation, the discounted payback period approach is much more difficult to calculate than with the payback period method.

$c)$ They are three advantages of discounted payback period method below:

$i)$ A discounted cash flows are calculated using the discounted payback period method, as a reason, choosing an investment with such a negative net present value is impossible.

$ii)$ The discounted payback period makes it simple to make investment decisions, an investment only with the shortest time horizon must be chosen.

$iii)$ Investments having a longer payback period benefit from the discounted payback period, a project with the shortest cost-covering time would have more liquidity because it would have a longer capability to create excess cash flows.
